metadata.title: INCIDENCES SOCIOECONOMIQUES DES PRATIQUES DE GESTION DURABLE DES TERRES AGRICOLES DANS LA COMMUNE DE SINENDE AU BENIN
metadata.description:
Land degradation threatens agriculture in Sub-Saharan Africa. This study assesses the determinants of adoption and the socio-economic impact of Sustainable Land Management (SLM) practices for maize production in Sinendé, a semi-arid commune in Northern Benin. A mixed-methods approach combined a quantitative survey of 150 stratified farm households (including 30% female-headed households) and 15 qualitative interviews with key stakeholders. Analyses (logistic/linear regression, cost comparison) were performed using R.

Key findings indicate that access to agricultural credit is the main enabling factor for SLM adoption (OR ≈ 1.65). Conversely, support from extension agents shows a negative correlation, while conventional socio-demographic factors are non-significant. SLM adoption reduces maize production costs by approximately 25%. Economically, organic fertilization offers the highest profitability (net margin, capital productivity), whereas organo-mineral fertilization maximizes yield per hectare. The combined application of multiple SLM measures is positively correlated with increased farm income.

SLM practices are economically beneficial in Sinendé, but their adoption is hindered by financial barriers and the potential inadequacy of extension services. Recommendations include improving access to suitable credit, reforming agricultural advisory services to integrate local knowledge, and encouraging combinations of SLM practices tailored to farmers’ objectives. Integrating these elements into public policies is crucial for sustainable and resilient agriculture.

Keywords: Socioeconomic impact, Sustainable Land Management, agricultural practices, Agricultural land, Sinendé.

journal.title: Revue Internationale de la Recherche Scientifique (Revue-IRS) - ISSN : 2958-8413

data.title: INCIDENCES SOCIOECONOMIQUES DES PRATIQUES DE GESTION DURABLE DES TERRES AGRICOLES DANS LA COMMUNE DE SINENDE AU BENIN

metadata.title: Cosmology of Quantum Triadic Graphs
metadata.description:
This paper presents Cosmology of Quantum Triadic Graphs: Structural Emergence in the Relational Time Superposition Hypothesis (RTSH) Model, the first computational formulation of a cosmological network governed by quantum-inspired causal rules. In this model, new nodes attach to a growing causal graph through a Grover-based quantum selection mechanism, followed by a coherence-driven quantum triadic closure and a semilocal causal noise term.

The resulting networks exhibit filamentary and quasi-spherical morphologies, high clustering coefficients, truncated power-law degree distributions, and small-world causal coherence — structural signatures reminiscent of the large-scale cosmic web. The paper interprets these properties within the RTSH framework, where spacetime emerges as a self-optimizing network of quantum collapses.

To our knowledge, this is the first formulation of a quantum triadic closure mechanism — a coherence-driven analogue of classical triadic closure — designed to capture local reinforcement of causal correlations in quantum-relational networks.

The full simulation code (Qiskit + NetworkX + Matplotlib) is included as Appendix C and reproduces all figures and metrics discussed in the text.

Keywords:
RTSH, quantum networks, causal graphs, triadic closure, Grover algorithm, emergent spacetime, complex systems, cosmology of graphs.
references: Penrose, R. (1996). On Gravity's Role in Quantum State Reduction. General Rela tivity and Gravitation, 28(5), 581–600
Penrose, R. (2016). Fashion, Faith, and Fantasy in the New Physics of the Universe.  Princeton University Press
Grover, L. K. (1997). Quantum Mechanics Helps in Searching for a Needle in a  Haystack. Physical Review Letters, 79(2), 325–328
Barabási, A.-L., & Albert, R. (1999). Emergence of Scaling in Random Networks.  Science, 286(5439), 509–512
Watts, D. J., & Strogatz, S. H. (1998). Collective Dynamics of 'Small-World' Net works. Nature, 393(6684), 440–442
Sorkin, R. D. (2003). Causal Sets: Discrete Gravity. In A. Gomberoff & D. Marolf  (Eds.), Lectures on Quantum Gravity (pp. 305–327). Springer
Gonçalves, C. (2025). Relational Time Superposition Hypothesis (RTSH) (Versão v4). Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.16623845

metadata.title: Pan-Arctic Gateway transports since 2004
metadata.description:
This data set encompasses input data and adjusted data derived with an inverse model of ocean velocity, temperature and salinity obtained from ocean moorings and hydrography from the four main Arctic Gateways Fram Strait, Barents Sea Opening, Bering Strait and Davis Strait. The data are provided as monthly averages and are gridded on vertical (gateway) sections with 4 m vertical distance and 3 km horizontal spacing. Derived data products of pan-Arctic net heat transport and freshwater transport obtained from the inverse-model adjusted data fields are also provided.

The data set starts in October 2004 and initially is provided up to May 2022. Newer versions of the data sets (e.g. updates/extensions in time, or adjustments in set up/approach) will be uploaded once available.

The mooring data from the Arctic Gateways are provided by the Norwegian Polar Institute (Tromsø, Norway), the Alfred Wegener Institute (Bremerhaven, Germany), the Institute for Marine Research (Bergen, Norway) and the Applied Physics Laboratory, Univ. of Washington (Seattle, USA).

metadata.title: GENBoostGPU: GPU-accelerated elastic net boosting for large-scale epigenomics
metadata.description: GENBoostGPU provides a scalable framework for running elastic net regression with boosting across thousands of CpG sites, leveraging GPU acceleration with RAPIDS cuML, CuPy, and cuDF. It supports SNP preprocessing, cis-window filtering, LD clumping, missing data imputation, and phenotype integration — all optimized for large-scale epigenomics.
metadata.notes: If you use GENBoostGPU in your research, please cite this software using the provided DOI.

data.title: GENBoostGPU: GPU-accelerated elastic net boosting for large-scale epigenomics

metadata.title: Data repository for study on dinoflagellate bioluminescence and toxicity in response to copepodamides
metadata.description:
Overview

This repository contains the datasets and analysis code for the manuscript "Grazer-induced bioluminescence and toxicity in marine dinoflagellates" by Gonzalo-Valmala and colleagues, published as an original research article in Limnology & Oceanography (https://doi.org/10.1002/lno.70255).

Analysis code and output

This repository includes an R Markdown file (Supplementary_Code.Rmd) containing all code used for data analysis and visualization. It provides a fully reproducible workflow for statistical analyses, correlation assessments, effect size calculations, and figure generation. The corresponding Supplementary_Code.html file is the compiled output of the R Markdown file, displaying both the code and its execution results.

Datasets

P.reticulatum_Bioluminescence.csv: This dataset is used for Michaelis-Menten curve fitting and statistical analysis of the bioluminescence induction response observed in Protoceratium reticulatum under increasing copepodamide concentrations. It also provides the data for the correlation analysis between net bioluminescence production rates and net growth rates, as well as for generating figures 1b, d, and f of the main manuscript.

A.catenella_Bioluminescence.csv: This dataset is used for Michaelis-Menten curve fitting and statistical analysis of the bioluminescence induction response observed in Alexandrium catenella under increasing copepodamide concentrations. It also provides the data for the correlation analysis between net bioluminescence production rate and net growth rates, as well as for generating figures 1a, c, and e of the main manuscript.

G.catenatum_Wide.csv: Contains the primary data used for the statistical analysis and correlation analysis (net toxicity production rate vs. net growth rates) for the toxin production in Gymnodinium catenatum upon increasing copepodamide concentrations. It is also used to produce figures 2a, c, and e of the main manuscript.

G.catenatum_Long.csv: Provides the data to produce figure 2a.

A.catenella_Toxin_Wide.csv: Contains the primary data used for the statistical analysis and correlation analysis (net toxicity production rate vs. net growth rates) for the toxin production in Alexandrium catenella upon increasing copepodamide concentrations, as well as to produce figures 2d and 2f of the main manuscript and figure S1 of the supplementary information.

A.catenella_Toxins_Long.csv: Provides the data to produce figure 2b.

Both_species_bioluminescence.csv: Contains the data to compute the summary statistics (number of replicates, mean, standard deviation, standard error, 95% confidence intervals, and lower and higher confidence intervals) used for the effect size calculations in the bioluminescence induction experiments of Protoceratium reticulatum and Alexandrium catenella (Table 3).

EffectSizeBiolum_Data.csv: Contains the data needed to produce the percent effect size calculations between treatment and control groups for the bioluminescence induction experiment in Protoceratium reticulatum and Alexandrium catenella, as well as the rest of the elements observed in Table 2.

Both_species_Toxins.csv: Contains the necessary data to compute the summary statistics (number of replicates, mean, standard deviation, standard error, 95% confidence intervals, and lower and higher confidence intervals) used for the effect size calculations in the toxin induction experiments of Alexandrium catenella and Gymnodinium catenatum (Table 3).

EffectSizeTox_Data.csv: Contains the data needed to produce the percent effect size calculations between treatment and control groups for the bioluminescence induction experiment in Alexandrium catenella and Gymnodinium catenatum, as well as the rest of the elements observed in Table 3.

Alexandrium_catenella_(1).PNG: This .png file contains a dinoflagellate drawing of Alexandrium catenella used in figures 1a and 2b.

Protoceratium_reticulatum_(1).PNG: This .png file contains a dinoflagellate drawing of Protoceratium reticulatum used in figure 1b.

Gymnodinium_catenatum_(1).PNG: This .png file contains a dinoflagellate drawing of Gymnodinium catenatum inserted in figure 2a.

metadata.title: BETA-FOR_SP5_Decomposition_CowDung_rapid_assessment_2024-2025
metadata.description: This data set contains removal rates of cow dung on the BETA-FOR rapid assessment patches measured in spring 2024 and 2025. Cow dung samples were accessible to all invertebrate detritivores (insect_exclusion = False).
metadata.notes:
Variables Description
################

*patchLabel_BETAFOR: unique BETA-FOR patch label

*patch: patch number

*subpatch: ID of subpatch located on the patch

*substrate_type: type of sample used, CD = cow dung

*dungID: unique ID for each cow dung collection. Cow dung for this experiment was collected from cows at Naturlandhof Peter (Schwebheim, Germany).

*insect_exclusion: True = sample was covered by an insect net, False = sample was accessible for insects

*start_date: start date of exposure of the sample to patch conditions

*weight_start_wet: wet weight of sample at the start of the exposure 

*weight_start_dry: estimated dry weight of sample at the start of the exposure. Dry weight was estimated using wet to dry ratios of 5 control samples for each dungID.

*end_date: end date of exposure of the sample to patch conditions

*weight_end_wet: wet weight of sample at the end of the exposure

*weight_end_dry: dry weight of sample at the end of the exposure. Samples were dried at 100 °C for 5 days. 

*exposure_time: number of days the samples were exposed to patch conditions

*removal_rate: (weight_start_dry - weight_end_dry )/ weight_start_dry

*removal_rate_day: ((weight_start_dry - weight_end_dry ) / weight_start_dry) / exposure_time

*year: year in which the experiment took place

*season: season in which the experiment took place. Removal rates were measured twice, once in spring and once in late summer. 

*data_collector: person collecting the data and supervising field work teams

metadata.title: BETA-FOR_SP5_Decomposition_RatCarcass_rapid_assessment_2024-2025
metadata.description: This data set contains decomposition rates of rat carcasses on the BETA-FOR rapid assessment patches measured in late summer 2024 and 2025. Rat carcasses were accessible to all invertebrate detritivores (insect_exclusion = False).
metadata.notes:
Variables Description
################

*patchLabel_BETAFOR: unique BETA-FOR patch label

*patch: patch number

*subpatch: ID of subpatch located on the patch

*substrate_type: type of sample used, rat = rat carcass

*insect_exclusion: True = sample was covered by an insect net, False = sample was accessible for insects

*start_date: start date of exposure of the sample to patch conditions

*weight_start_wet: wet weight of sample at the start of the exposure 

*end_date: end date of exposure of the sample to patch conditions

*weight_end_wet: wet weight of sample at the end of the exposure

*rat_position: position of rat at the end of the exposure. On_top: rat was found on top of the forest floor, half_soil: rat was dragged half into the soil by decomposers, in_soil: rat was buried completely in the soil, stolen: rat was taken away by vertebrate scavengers

*exposure_time: number of days the samples were exposed to patch conditions

*decomposition_rate: (weight_start_dry - weight_end_dry )/ weight_start_dry

*year: year in which the experiment took place

*insect_exclusion_fail: TRUE: insect net was breached by decomposers, FALSE: insect net was intact, or sample was not covert by insect net

*season: season in which the experiment took place. Removal rates were measured twice, once in spring and once in late summer. 

*data_collector: person collecting the data and supervising field work teams
